Graphical abstract The covalent organic framework (COF) membranes, with their ordered structure and permanent porosity, address challenges like dendrite growth and interfacial instability in alkali metal batteries, enabling high-performance and safe energy storage systems. Noteworthy challenges such as severe side reactions, interfacial instability, and dendrite growth have plagued rechargeable alkali metal batteries for a long time. Alleviating the plight necessitates innovative membranes capable of modulating ion transport and establishing stable interfaces. The exploration of implemented membranes with thermal/mechanical and electrochemical stability is crucial for achieving high-performance and safe alkali metal batteries. Crystalline covalent organic framework (COF) membranes have emerged as promising materials for next-generation energy storage systems due to their tunable porosity and exceptional physicochemical properties. This review specifically examines the critical role of COF membranes in enabling sustainable alkali metal (Li/Na/K) batteries, with a particular focus on design principles, performance advantages, and key challenges of COF membranes. The discussion emphasizes structure-property relationships specifically relevant to rechargeable battery applications, supported by recent decades of research. Impressively, this mini review further identifies three critical research frontiers: reticular chemistry-guided materials design, multifunctional composite architectures, and in-situ characterization techniques. This targeted analysis provides actionable insights for developing COF membranes that address the fundamental limitations of current alkali metal battery technologies. Keywords Rechargeable alkali metal batteries Crystalline covalent organic framework membranes Design principles Performance advantages Key challenges Structure-property relationships 1 Introduction The increase in global energy demand and the emergence of renewable energy have intensified the utilization and development of reliable energy storage systems. This trend has spurred plentiful efforts to optimize material innovation and structural designs of batteries to satisfy the escalating desirability for higher energy density, extended longevity, and guaranteed safety [1–5]. Rechargeable alkali metal batteries (RAMBs) (Li, Na, K-based systems) have triggered considerable relevant research due to their distinct attributes for adaptable application conditions. However, inevitable concerns, including uncontrollable dendrite growth, severe side reactions, interfacial instability, and limited ion conduction still plague their practical application for portable energy storage devices [6–8]. Fortunately, precise material selection and structural design have been proven to be effective solutions to alleviate the challenges above. Hence, the shift towards more sustainable materials and manufacturing methods is crucial for accelerating the use of advanced RAMBs in portable devices and new energy vehicles. Inspired by the precisely mediating transmembrane transport of natural membrane proteins, membrane engineering has gained exciting progress in the fields of separation [9,10], purification [11,12], molecular/ionic transport [13,14], and energy storage/conversion [15–17] due to the process intensification originating from modularity, inherent low energy consumption, and high efficiency [18,19]. Compared with traditional polymer membranes with low thermal stability and poor ion selectivity, great efforts in adopting functional biomimetic membranes with incredible electrochemical performance have been invested in improving the energy density, cycling lifespan, and safety of various energy storage systems [20–22]. Numerous studies have demonstrated the feasibility of the functional membranes with artificial nanochannels, transporters, and specific stabilities used in separators [23,24], solid electrolytes [25–27], and electrode/electrolyte interlayers of existing secondary batteries [28–30], achieving fast ion transport and strengthening electrochemical performance. Therefore, it is meaningful to explore functional membranes with precise pathways of ion transport favorable to the practicality of RAMBs. Covalent organic frameworks (COFs) with long-range ordered structure, a type of crystalline materials consisting of lightweight elements (C, H, O, N, S, etc.), exhibit excellent gas storage capabilities and micro separation effects between molecules or ions due to the tunable porosity, structural stability, and functional diversity [31,32]. Impressively, COFs with uniformly dispersed active sites, continuous ion-conduction pathways, and thermal/chemical stability provide a guarantee for the improved electrochemical performance of RAMBs. Nevertheless, the synthesis procedures for COFs through solvothermal methods often emerge as stacked or block-like powders, resulting in insolubility in common solvents and high thermal stability with no melting observed at elevated temperatures. Such lack of processability significantly hampers their potential for large-scale application. Thus, devising feasible strategies to fabricate high-performance COF membranes could stimulate the potential of COFs in energy storage/conversion [33]. The as-constructed COF membranes can provide more possibilities for realizing high energy density, high safety, and environmentally friendly batteries through the design of the explicit structure and the introduction of specific functional groups (Scheme 1 ) [34,35]. The following contents summarize the design and synthesis, fabrication strategies, and application of COF membranes in advanced RAMBs in recent years, thereby accelerating the commercialization of COFs in secondary batteries. 2 Design and synthesis of COFs and COF membranes 2.1 Structural features of COFs Similar to metal-organic frameworks, COFs represent a class of crystalline porous materials distinguished by highly ordered structures and tunable porosity. The frameworks are constructed by modular synthesis of robust covalent bonds, such as boron-based linkages (B–O) [36], imine-based linkages (C=N) [37], hydrazone-based linkages (C=N–NH2) [38], and C=C linkages [39]. This process involves the precise linkage of organic building blocks, including boronic acids, amines, and aldehydes, to promote the corresponding boronate ester formation, imine condensation, triazine integration, or sp 2-C formation. The modular characteristics of COFs synthesis enable precise control over pore aperture, geometry, topological structure, and surface functionality, rendering them highly versatile for a wide range of applications. 2.1.1 Characteristics of pore channels One of the most distinctive features of COFs is the well-defined pore arrangement, which can range from microporous to mesoporous dimensions. The pores are usually uniform in size and shape, allowing precise control of molecular sieving and ion transport. Additionally, the combination of lightweight, low-density, and high surface areas for COFs makes the materials ideal for applications requiring efficient mass transport and high adsorption capacities. The processability to functionalize COFs with specific chemical groups (anion, cation, and lipophilic/hydrophilic groups) further enhances the properties of the material, allowing for tailored interactions with ions, molecules, or gases. The structural attributes coupled with thermal and chemical stability allow COFs to be promising materials for energy storage, catalysis, and separation technologies. There are several approaches for regulating pore structures, including pore size and pore micro-environment regulation [40–43]. The framework can be adjusted by altering the structure or properties of the organic monomers at the conception stage or implementing modification on the structure after the fabrication. Specifically, the various dimensions and configurations of COFs from 0D to 3D can be developed by regulating organic units, thereby achieving precise construction of framework structures with specific functional characteristics in terms of structure-activity relationships [40] (Fig. 1 a). For pore wall decoration, three types of B@TP-COF, B@DMTP-COF and B@DVA-COF heterojunctions, varied from hydrogen, methoxyl, to vinyl groups were designed, enhanced acoustic sensitizer performance achieved through fine-tuning of monomer and connected molecular structures [41] (Fig. 1b). Additionally, pre-introducing large side chain groups or some large functional groups into the monomer structure is an effective strategy for the tunable pore size to achieve specific effects [42,44] (Fig. 1c). Yang et al. and Zhang et al. respectively designed COFs with better separation and ion transport capabilities [45,46]. Relevant functional groups introduced through the design of the pore structure can serve as catalytic sites to obstruct the migration of by-products and further promote the targeted ion conduction. Another strategy based on host-guest interaction can also achieve size sieving effect or accelerate ion transport by cutting holes or changing the in-pore environment [43] (Fig. 1d). Wang et al. [47] reported rapid lithium ion conduction achieved by introducing lithium-friendly PEG as a plasticizer into the COFs skeleton. Therefore, modification of the pore structure can maximize the use of the highly oriented pore structure characteristics of the host material [48–50]. 2.1.2 Geometries of COFs The geometry is a solid foundation for the design of COFs, enabling precise control over the structural and functional properties. COFs can be classified into four types: 0-dimensional (0D), 1-dimensional (1D), 2-dimensional (2D), and 3-dimensional (3D) according to different dimensions of the covalent linkage framework [51–54] (Fig. 2 ). This structural diversity combined with the inherent porosity and functionality of COFs could endow the material with the potential to serve as a platform for addressing challenges of energy, catalysis, and separation technologies. 2D COFs are the most widely studied type and are characterized by layered structures where planar building blocks form extended sheets. These sheets are typically stacked through non-covalent interactions, such as π-π stacking, to create a layered framework. The geometry of the individual layers depends on the symmetry of the building blocks and the type of covalent linkages. 3D COFs have a variety of topological structure types due to their diverse selection of structural building blocks and offer unique advantages due to their interconnected pore systems and higher structural complexity. These frameworks are formed by linking tetrahedral or trigonal building blocks, resulting in a three-dimensional cross-linked network. Beyond simple 2D and complex 3D structures, COFs can exhibit hierarchical geometries that combine multiple pore sizes and shapes within a single framework. Specifically, 2D COFs with specific 1D channels are the ideal candidates for applications inducing uniform ion transport for lithium-ion batteries [55]. 3D COFs with specific diamondoid (dia) topologies demonstrate exceptional performance in both ionic conduction (proton, Li+, and Na+) and gas storage applications, owing to their high specific surface area and fully interconnected 3D pore network [56,57]. The designability of COFs with specific geometries allows researchers to customize special properties for targeted applications, from energy storage and catalysis to environmental remediation. From the Reticular Chemistry Structure Resource (RCSR) database, various subdivisions of crystal materials currently constructed for grid chemistry can be obtained [58–60]. By leveraging the symmetry and connectivity of organic building blocks, it is possible to guide the design/construction of 1D, 2D, and 3D COFs with various topological structures, which describes the connectivity and spatial arrangement of the building blocks within the framework, for different fields such as energy storage, catalysis, and separation. However, the design and construction of chemical topology structures for COFs are mostly based on 2D and 3D nanostructures, originating from the design/choice of the building blocks. 2D COFs exhibit well-defined layered architectures, where organic building blocks are interconnected via strong in-plane covalent bonds, while interlayer cohesion is maintained through non-covalent interactions (π-π stacking, hydrogen bonding, and van der Waals forces). Among these, 2D COFs with uniform one-dimensional nanochannels demonstrate exceptional chemical/thermal stability and optoelectronic properties and can be systematically classified into distinct topological categories, including tetragonal, hexagonal, rhombic, trigonal, etc. [58] (Fig. 3 a). Different chemical topological structures can have a significant impact on their properties, especially in three-dimensional materials where the topological structure determines the pore structure, properties, and potential applications of the three-dimensional framework. Since Yaghi et al. first reported three-dimensional COFs in 2007, there have been only a few topological structures in three-dimensional COFs, including bor, dia, lon-b-3c, pts, ffc, ctn, dia-C, pts-C, srs-C, rra, etc., and exploration of new structures remains the forefront direction in this field [59] (Fig. 3b). The preparation of three-dimensional crystal structures and the determination of their structures remain the two major challenges in developing new topologies. Although research on COF topology is currently in full swing, the design and synthesis of new topologies, as well as elucidating their mechanisms of action in ion conduction, gas adsorption/separation, sensing, and catalysis, are still the focus of future research. At the same time, they provide forward-looking guidance for the construction of functional COF membranes. 2.1.3 Surface functionalities of COFs The various surface characteristics by the precise regulation during the synthesis of COFs play a significant role in determining their functionality and performance in catalysis, gas storage, separation, and energy conversion/storage [48,61–63], which is based on the chemical composition, porosity, and functional groups present on the surface of the porous material [64–66]. The high surface area and porosity of COFs provide abundant active sites for interactions with molecules, ions, or gases to enhance their capacity for adsorption, catalysis, and ion transport, emphasizing the importance of COFs for applications such as gas storage (H2, CO2, etc.) and electrochemical energy storage [61] (Fig. 4 a). In addition, one of the most distinctive characteristics of COFs is the feasibility to incorporate specific functional groups onto their surfaces during synthesis or through post-synthetic modifications, enabling precise control over surface chemistry. Common functional groups can be divided into three types: polar groups (–OH, –COOH, –NH2, etc.), non-polar groups (–CH3, –C6H5, etc.), and redox-active groups (e.g., quinones, triazines) [62] (Fig. 4b). Besides, the surface charge and polarity (negatively/positively charged surfaces and neutral/amphiphilic surfaces) of COFs can be adjusted by incorporating charged or polar functional groups [48] (Fig. 4c). Specifically, some COFs are designed with dynamic or stimulus-responsive surfaces that can change properties in response to external triggers, such as pH, temperature, or light [63] (Fig. 4d). Owing to this adaptability, COFs are highly versatile for smart materials and sensing applications. 2.2 Scalable fabrication strategies for COF membranes Several strategies have been developed for efficiently manufacturing universal large-scale COF membranes and COF-matrix composite membranes, which can be mainly divided into bottom-up and top-down methods [67–70] (Fig. 5 ). The bottom-up strategies, including in-situ growth, interfacial polymerization, electrospinning, and electrophoretic deposition, are used to assemble small structural units (atoms, molecules, nanoparticles, etc.) into relatively larger and more complex structural systems [5,71,72]. On the contrary, the top-down preparation strategies involve the exfoliation of larger sizes into nanostructures by a mechanical process and reassembling smaller materials into macroscopic materials. The 2D layer stacked structure of most COFs can be processed into nanosheets by top-down exfoliation or bottom-up direct growth [73–75]. Inheriting the unique characteristics of COFs, adopting COF membranes with high processability and flexibility will be beneficial for achieving their large-scale applications in many fields, especially in the application with separators, solid ion-conductors, electrode/electrolyte interlayers, and other applications for rechargeable energy storage systems [76–79]. 2.2.1 Precise structural design of COF membranes The precise design of COF membranes is usually synthesized by the “bottom-up” approach of interfacial polymerization, space-confined polymerization, and sacrificial template strategies. Interfacial polymerization is a one-step polycondensation at the interface of two immiscible phases, which has been utilized to prepare membranes of materials with poor processability [46]. Dey et al. [80] proposed a pioneered preparation of large-scale COF membranes by water/organic two-phase interfacial polymerization. However, conventional water-organic interfacial polymerization is not suitable for the fabrication of COF membranes by poorly water-soluble aromatic amine monomers. Moreover, the development of ultrathin COF membranes represents an essential direction in advanced membranes [81]. Precise control of the membrane preparation process in terms of kinetics and thermodynamics can ensure the stable structure and properties of the prepared ultrathin COF membranes. Although the interface aggregation method provides a feasible strategy for preparing self-supporting COF membranes, the deficiency to scale up the preparation and poor mechanical properties still limit the practicality of this method. Space-confined polymerization is a cutting-edge synthetic strategy that involves conducting polymerization reactions within nanoscale or microscale confined spaces, such as porous materials, templates, or self-assembled structures. This approach leverages the physical and chemical constraints imposed by the confined environment to control the growth, morphology, and properties of the resulting polymers. By tailoring the dimensions and surface characteristics of the confinement space, researchers can achieve precise control over polymer architecture, molecular weight, and functionality, which are often unattainable through conventional bulk polymerization methods. Geng et al. [82] proposed a new space-confined polymerization strategy for the preparation of continuous COF membranes, including 2D N-COF membranes and 3D COF-300 membranes, achieving great gas separation performance. Additionally, the polymerization within the pores of COFs or other ordered microporous polymers can create conductive polymer networks with high ion transport efficiency. In addition, using polymeric substrates to prepare flexible and expandable COF membranes is also a method with great application value. Sacrificial templating is a powerful and versatile strategy for fabricating COF membranes with precise control over their structure, porosity, and functionality [83,84]. This method involves using a temporary template to guide the growth of COFs, which is subsequently removed to leave behind a well-defined membrane structure. Zhang et al. [85] proposed a method based on polymer template-assisted preparation of self-supporting COF membranes for the preparation of large-area COF membrane electrolytes, achieving significantly enhanced electrochemical performance and safe solid-state lithium metal batteries. Although these methods are commonly used to prepare self-supporting defect-free COF membranes, they are also applicable to the preparation of COF-matrix composite membranes (integrating COFs with polymers or inorganic materials). Zhao et al. [68] reported the preparation of triphenylamine-based COF-matrix composite membranes on polymeric substrate by interface polymerization induced by oligomers. 2.2.2 Exfoliation-based assembly techniques Layer-by-layer (LbL), a “top-down” assembly strategy (exfoliation-based assembly), is proposed to prepare COF-based membranes. Shi et al. [86] achieved a rapid synthesis of imine-linked COF membranes at room temperature through the LbL process and demonstrated enhanced dye separation performance. Similarly, Zhang et al. [87] developed a simple LbL stacking process to prepare 2D cationic COF membranes, which exhibited high sieving for dye molecules/ions of different charges and sizes. Although the top-down preparation process has advantages for preparing simple COF membranes, it is usually strenuous and difficult to implement for the preparation of flawless COF membranes with excellent mechanical properties [81,88–90]. Therefore, most studies are based on the preparation of COF composite matrix membranes and their extraordinary roles in different research directions. Sun et al. [91] reported the fabrication of ultrathin (7.1 µm) hetero-layered Kevlar/COF composite-matrix membranes by spin coating as LBL assembly to precisely control the structure and thickness of the resulting solid electrolyte. In a word, the preparation of COF-matrix composite membranes provides a practical and feasible approach for the practical application of COFs in various fields. 2.2.3 Particle morphology and size effects on COF membranes performance The morphology and size of COF membranes have a significant impact on their performance, mainly reflected in the surface charge properties, ion conductivity, and other aspects of the membrane. Yang et al. [92] screened suitable reaction-diffusion conditions by changing the reaction pathway between Schiff-base and aldehyde monomer, thus preparing Turing COF membranes with controllable stacking and uniform pore structure in maze stripe or spot patterns, endowing COF membranes with efficient molecular sieving ability in organic solvent nanofiltration (Fig. 6 a). Sekhar Sasmal et al. [93] proposed direct nucleation simultaneously strategy for COF membranes, exhibiting the ability to tune the size of the COF nanospheres from 25 to 570 nm. The COF membranes exhibit significant performance in gas selective separation (Fig. 6b). Impressively, the ion conductivity and ion transport kinetics in secondary alkali metal batteries can be significantly improved by controlling the particle size and morphology of COF membranes. Zhu et al. [94] reported the fabrication of a 3D COF-SO3H membrane adopting an interfacial polymerization strategy by dual acid-mediated, exhibiting enhanced proton conductivity (843 mS cm−1, 90 °C) (Fig. 6c). Shi et al. [95] developed a surface-hydrogen-bonded (SHB) network architecture on ionic COF membranes through precision grafting of high-density, spatially ordered hydrophilic functional groups, achieving an unexpected ultrahigh proton conductivity (1389 mS cm−1, 90 °C, 100% RH) (Fig. 6d). However, there is currently relatively little research on the application of COF grain morphology and size in secondary alkali metal batteries. Clarifying the structure-activity relationship between morphology and size, ion conductivity, and electrochemical performance is of great guiding significance for constructing functional characteristic COF membranes for application in secondary energy storage batteries. 2.3 Key characteristics of COF membranes The characteristics of hydrophilicity/hydrophobicity, chemical/thermal stability, and processability are key parameters for COF membranes [96]. This versatility in functionalization allows COF membranes to make specific interactions with target molecules or ions, improving their performance in selective separations, catalytic processes, and ionic transport (Fig. 7 ). COF-matrix composite membranes have received significant attention for adsorption and separation attributed to their large specific surface area, well-arranged pore distribution, and unique lipophilic/hydrophilic surface properties resulting from customizable functionalization. By utilizing strategies such as surface functionalization, gradient regulation of pore wall wettability, and organic/inorganic composites, COF membranes can break through the limited “trade-off” effect of traditional separation membranes. The thermal stability of traditional polymer and COF membranes varies significantly depending on their chemical composition, molecular structure, and processing conditions. While some conventional polymers (polyethylene or polypropylene) exhibit relatively low thermal stability with decomposition temperatures below 300 °C, other polymers, particularly those with rigid backbones or aromatic structures (polyimides, polyether ether ketone, and polytetrafluoroethylene), demonstrate exceptional thermal resilience. In contrast, COF membranes, constructed by strong covalent bonds and featuring rigid, aromatic frameworks, generally exhibit high thermal stability, with many COFs remaining stable above 500 °C. Specifically, compared to traditional linear polymers and cross-linked co-polymers, the specific microporous organic framework and functional active sites of COF membranes provide an ideal platform for ion transport. Importantly, these unique characteristics allow COFs to improve interfacial contacts of energy storage devices, promoting uniform metal ion deposition on electrodes for alkali-metal batteries [97–100]. The surface charge of functional membranes is a crucial factor to consider, as demonstrated by the case of lithium-ion batteries. The Li-ion conduction is influenced by various aspects, including the pore size of separators and the electrostatic interaction between surface charges and Li+. Moreover, surface charges can impact the dissociation of relevant molecules in the electrolyte. The diversity of functional structures based on COFs provides a possible way for regulating the surface charge of functional membranes [101]. The manipulation of charge on the framework by pre-modified monomer or post-synthetic modification methods has been proven to be a feasible method. Xu et al. [102] synthesized sulfonic acid-rich COFs which exhibited more electronegative compared to the traditional COFs without sulfonic acid groups. The COF-based membranes with excellent performance in rechargeable batteries can be obtained through functional tuning, which is a promising research prospect. 3 Applications of COF membranes in alkali metal batteries The prosperity of membrane science hastens the emergence of more relevant functional COF membranes, which indicates the exciting prospects of COF membranes in the field of rechargeable batteries. The homogeneity of the COFs structure favors interfacial compatibility, thereby reducing corrosion and smoothing of nucleation seeds by homogenizing ion flux. This section will introduce some applications of COF membranes in rechargeable batteries and the practical plight they face [103–106] (Fig. 8 ). 3.1 COF membranes in/for separators Separators serve to prevent direct contact between electrodes and provide a certain pore structure to facilitate stable metal ion transport. Nevertheless, commercial separators suffer from drawbacks such as inadequate thermal stability and limited affinity with the electrolyte. These shortcomings impede the fulfillment of battery safety requirements and restrict advancements in electrochemical performance. Some strategies have been employed to alleviate these concerns such as interfacial modification or developing novel types of materials for separators. Recent studies have demonstrated batteries with COFs-based separators exhibit improved electrochemical performance compared to commercially available polypropylene and polyethylene separators [33,103]. Different from these polymers, the employment of COFs provides stable regular one-dimensional channels over a wide range of temperatures and displays negligible change for temperature-dependent phase transitions. The support properties of polymer separators allow for the convenient fabrication of COF interlayers on substrates by vacuum filtration. Han et al. [107] prepared COFs/polypropylene composite membranes by depositing COF nanosheets on the surface of commercial polypropylene separators for excellent ion conduction and efficient immobilization of polysulfides. Kang et al. [108] proposed to combine polyvinylidene difluoride with electrochemically inert COFs containing cyanide groups (sp 2C-COFs) to effectively minimize undesired lithium loss and facilitate the formation of the inorganic-rich solid electrolyte interface. Similarly, Wen et al. [109] reported a novel polymer separator prepared by applying COFs as the coating layer and exhibited improved lithium transference number and cycle stability. Different from the above, self-supporting functional COF membranes reveal more advantageous potential in alkali-metal batteries. The self-supporting TPB-BD(OH)2-COF membranes [99] were designed where the hydrogen bonding network was conducive to the aggregation of electrolytes, thereby alleviating interactions of free solvents and lithium metals. COFs with specific 1D channels can regulate effectively the uniform deposition of metal ions during cycling, exhibiting outstanding stability and capacity retention. Shi et al. [110] prepared COF-TpPa-SO3H@rGO composite-matrix membranes as separators for Li-S batteries, which showed high charge/discharge specific capacity and long-term stability. In addition, chemical modification of polymer networks with lithium sulfonated groups can improve the lithium transference number to alleviate the wasteful electrolyte consumption and endow COF separators with enhanced electronegativity to suppress anions transport. The utilization of sulfonate-rich COF-based (SCOF-2) separators with strong electrostatic repulsion effects can effectively suppress the polysulfide shuttle, leading to enhanced rate performance of Li-S batteries [102,111]. Moreover, the benefits application of COF separators have been addressed in rechargeable sodium batteries. Kang et al. [112] first synthesized a self-supported sp 2C-conjugated catalytic COF separator, which can induce the formation of a favorable NaF-rich rather than unstable NaPF6 solid electrolyte interface to inhibit the undesired dissolution of Na anode. Besides, numerous modification strategies have been employed to enhance the electrochemical performance and cycling stability of COF membranes, as shown in Table 1 . Through the rational design of COF architectures and precision manufacturing optimization, ideal COF membranes are obtained according to the design of demand-driven at the molecular/atomic level for various functional applications. However, the mechanism of action of COF-based separators in secondary batteries is still not clarified and comprehensive [113]. From Section 2.1, the size-sieving effect, electrostatic repulsion, adsorption, and catalytic effect are usually used to clarify the mechanism of ions in the SRBs, through the design and construction of COF structural for enhanced host-guest interaction. Despite these advantages, innovative manufacturing methods, sophisticated characterization strategies, and low-cost, high-performance, and scalable COF-based membranes remain the focus of future research on their mechanisms and applications for alkali metal secondary rechargeable batteries, fuel cells, and other electrochemical energy storage devices [99,112,114–117]. In summary, the defined porous structure of COFs constructs a continuous pathway for ions. It is conducive to the efficient control of ion deposition at electrode interfaces, preventing the formation of needle-like dendrites [118]. The highly customizable structure of COFs provides abundant active sites to catalyze or adsorb solvent molecules and soluble by-products generated during charge/discharge, thereby improving the cycle stability and coulomb efficiency of rechargeable batteries [119]. Abundant research has proven the incorporation of COFs into composite matrix membranes or applying self-supporting COF membranes as separators is an effective way to enhance ion transport. Nonetheless, the limitation of the fabricating process for COF membranes remains a significant obstacle impeding progress in fields of electrochemistry, such as the inhomogeneity of COFs coatings and inadequate mechanical properties of self-supporting membranes [120]. Further research is required to tackle relevant challenges for the practical implementation of COF separators in energy storage and conversion. 3.2 COF membranes for electrode/electrolyte interfaces (EEIs) The construction of a stable electrode-electrolyte interface (EEI) has been proven to be effective for cycling stability and lifespan of rechargeable batteries [15,121–124] (Fig. 9 ). The solid electrolyte interface (SEI) layer is one of the EEIs initiated from the reaction between anodes and electrolytes, undertaking the reversible de-interlation of Li+. However, this interfacial layer is not static. It will repeatedly collapse and eventually form a dynamic equilibrium interface, leading to the continuous consumption of electrodes and electrolytes and ultimately degrading the electrochemical performance of batteries [125]. Previous studies have demonstrated that the potential inside the ideal electrodes should remain constant. Unfortunately, the formation of dynamic interfaces would destroy the homogeneity of the internal potential [126]. Several strategies have been adopted to remedy a series of issues at the EEI, such as constructing an artificial anode/cathode electrolyte interface (SEI/CEI) [127,128], using electrode coatings [129,130], and combining functional additives with electrolytes [131,132]. Among them, COFs have offered solutions for constructing stable EEIs due to their unique microporous structure and ease of functionalization, thereby facilitating uniform ion deposition. COF membranes have emerged as promising candidates for artificial EEIs to improve the side reaction and lithium dendrite issues owing to exceptional functional designability and excellent electrochemical performance [77,105,133–135]. Recently, COF-based SEI has made remarkable progress in enhancing the stability of anode interfaces [104,136]. Song et al. employed COFs with the cyclopropane structure as Li-ion hosts to fabricate a highly ordered lithiophilic framework for inhibiting lithium dendrite growth [36]. Additionally, Wang et al. [121] successfully modified the crystal spherical COFs (S-COF) and adopted the artificial SEI to stabilize lithium metal anodes (Fig. 9a). The 1D-ordered channel of SEI could regulate the deposition of Li+ and further dissociate ions in the presence of polar Li-affinity groups. The TpTG-COF was selected as access to strengthen the SEI [137]. Its ultrathin nanonetwork structure facilitates the uniform ion distribution on the surface, thereby mitigating regional electric field polarization. Promoting the homogeneous migration of metal ions within the EEI can effectively suppress dendrite formation and mitigate the excessive dissolution of metals. Moreover, COFs can be incorporated into zinc-based batteries to address the undesired solution of zinc anodes. The Zn-friendly COFs (Ti6Cu3-COF) possess effects of space electric field that can be fabricated on a large scale on Zn foil by electrospray method [122]. As SEI with ideal micro space electrostatic field protective coating, Ti6Cu3-COF can serve as ion transport channels and improve the deposition kinetics (Fig. 9b). The dissolution of the cathode in liquid energy storage systems poses a significant challenge to their long-term stability [138,139]. Furthermore, the high reactivity of electrodes to commercial electrolytes seriously plagues the capacity retention and rate capability of cells. COFs show great potential in constructing artificial CEIs to solve cathode interface challenges. Jiang et al. [123]. proposed a mesoporous imine vinyl-COF (COF-V) that was inverse-vulcanized with sulfur and used as cathodes, which can suppress the shuttle effect of polysulfides, originating from the synergetic chemical covalent interacting with the vinyl groups and physical confinement by the mesoporous channels (Fig. 9c). This is a great strategy for continuously shuttling polysulfides and improving the stability of the S electrode. The introduction of COF-LZU1 by Xu et al. as a protective layer was proposed to mitigate the impact of space charge by interactions between functional groups, thereby inhibiting the dendrite growth [124] (Fig. 9d). As a functional protective layer, COFs exhibit unique advantages in stabilizing the interface while promoting rapid ion transport. Table 2 also lists some applications of COFs in EEI layers. Despite the advantages of protecting the EEIs, the in-situ formation of COF membranes directly often generates water (via the Schiff base reaction), which is unsuitable for reactive alkali metals (Li, Na, K, etc.) [29,140,141]. The introduction of pre-lithiated COF, in-situ polymerization on modified alkali metal anodes, and optimized synthesis methods are commonly used to alleviate the instability reaction of metal anodes during COF membrane synthesis [37,104,142,143]. Table 3 shows a comparison of design principles for COF-SEI from the perspective of performance. The feasible design of the COF-SEI protective layer can be carried out at the molecular level in the future [142,144–150]. However, there is a lack of more in-depth mechanistic studies of interfaces. Further investigation is required to delve into the intricate process of interface formation and ion transfer behavior between electrodes and electrolytes. COFs can be further developed to alleviate EEI concerns by optimizing the design of artificial interfaces, which can be inspired by the physical durability and the internal chemistry in conjunction with solvents and ions of COF membranes. 3.3 COF membranes for solid-state electrolytes (SSEs) Solid-state metal batteries employ solid-state electrolytes as opposed to traditional non-aqueous liquid organic electrolytes (carbonate-based electrolyte and ether-based electrolyte), whose options significantly mitigate the hidden safety risks associated with liquid leakage or explosion. Solid-state batteries exhibit substantial possibilities for applications in high-energy-density, high-safety, and environmental-friendly batteries with decreased side reactions [151–154]. Nevertheless, challenges persist in terms of the rigid interface of inorganic sintering tablet electrolytes or the inadequate ion conductivity of polymer electrolytes at room temperature, representing common obstacles in the development of solid-state electrolytes [155–157]. There is a trade-off between high mechanical properties and high ionic conductivity. Therefore, extensive research has focused on modifying materials to point at alleviating the inherent conflicts within host materials. As crystalline porous polymer materials, COFs deliver superior properties to polymers and inorganic crystalline materials owing to the defined structures, rendering the porous materials a promising candidate for constructing high-performance solid polymer electrolytes [158–160]. The flexibility of functional COF membranes can overcome the limitation of traditional COFs with a pristine powder state, making a promising direction for future solid-state electrolyte development. COF membrane-based electrolytes are divided mainly into two types in terms of ion conduction mechanism. When the frameworks contain ion-conducting groups, such as PEG chains or SO3H, ion transport occurs inside the frameworks after ion exchange through the interactions among functional groups. On the other hand, additional assistance is required in the case of the lack of ion-conducting groups. The introduction of plasticizers is the common method to deal with these issues where COF membranes serve as the host and regulate ion transport owing to the well-ordered structure. When supported by substrates, COF membranes have an upgraded mechanical strength whose cooperative effects of both influence ion conduction. Guo et al. [105] entrapped dimethylacetamide and LiTFSI (DMA@LiTFSI) within the pores of Li-COF. The flexible DMA chains possessed functional groups that facilitated the release of Li+ from rigid COFs. Besides, the flexible ultrathin COF membranes have remarkable mechanical toughness (Fig. 8c and Fig. 10 a). Niu et al. [151] converted imine-linked COF (I-COF) into stable quinoline-linked COFs (Q-COF), which displayed excellent mechanical strength to facilitate the suppression of Li dendrites (Fig. 10b). In addition, some conventional approaches have been adapted to alleviate the anxiety of low conductivity caused by the crystallization of polymer electrolytes at low temperatures. Hou et al. [152] grafted the ether‐based electrolytes to the designed V-COF via in-situ polymerization. V‐COF effectively reduced the crystallinity and glass transition temperature of the poly-ether matrix (Fig. 10c). Moreover, Guo et al. [47] encapsulated low-molecular-weight PEG into pores of COFs with anionic, neutral, or cationic scaffolds to promote ion conduction (Fig. 10d). Some innovative methods have been explored to enhance the performance of COF-based solid electrolytes. Li et al. [101] constructed a new cationic COFs (Im-COF-Br) and substituted counter-ion Br− with TFSI−, resulting in enhanced ion conductivity of COF-based electrolytes (4.64 × 10−4 S cm−1 at 353 K). The side reactions caused by anions in COF-based electrolytes impose restrictions on ion content within the framework, leading to insufficient ion transport capacity. Zhao et al. [153] designed COFs with different structures as anion‐free and single lithium-ion conductors (Fig. 10e). The specific framework could improve the interfacial stability and weaken polarization for high conductivity and low activation energy. Furthermore, incorporating plasticizers to improve the ion conductivity of COFs has been a common approach. This method encourages efficient ion conductivity, overcoming the inherent limitations imposed by temperature and traditional liquid-electrolyte systems. The design ability at the molecular/atomic scale enables COF membranes to utilize functional groups to exhibit enhanced ion conductivity, great ion rectification behavior, and long-cycling electrochemical stability, thereby facilitating fast charging and high-energy density solid-state batteries. However, several challenges still hinder the progress of COF-based electrolytes, including the morphology and size of COF particles, the crystal and orientation control of COFs, the lack of transport media, the strong Coulombic interaction between the host and guest, and the incomplete preparation method. Addressing these issues and further elucidating the ion transport mechanism of COF-based electrolytes is crucial for advancing the development of COF-based electrolytes. 3.4 COF membranes for anode/cathode The development of flexible self-supporting electrodes is an important research topic. However, the powder form of traditional COFs means that they can be prepared into membrane electrodes for use in batteries when combined with polymer binders. Yang et al. [106] reported a 2D polyimide-linked COF cathodes with great reversible electrochemical performance, originating from the high density-loading of redox-active centers and a mesoporous channel (Fig. 8d). Meanwhile, Wu et al. [161] proposed a dual optimization chemical design strategy for COF molecules and morphology to prepare high-performance cathodes for lithium-ion batteries, in order to achieve enhanced redox kinetics. In addition to being used as cathodes for secondary batteries, COFs can also be used as anodes. Cai et al. [162] synthesized a cheese morphology 2D nanoporous TP-COFs by microwave ultrasound coupling strategy, which was used as anodes for lithium-ion batteries for the first time, demonstrating significantly improved electrochemical performance and cycling stability. Despite the application in rechargeable batteries, COF-based membrane electrodes also have great application prospects in supercapacitors. For example, the organic electrodes on carbon foam by an in-situ Schiff-based reaction utilizing 2D COFs (DAB-COF) [163]. Additionally, the uniform integration of anthraquinone-based COFs (DAAQ-COF) into 2D MXene nanosheets had been achieved via a cation-driven self-assembly process, resulting in flexible carbonyl-containing COF/MXene composite membrane electrodes for flexible supercapacitor [164]. The highly designable structure, functionalization strategy, and permanent porosity of COFs materials make them have great potential for application in organic anode and cathodes for secondary rechargeable batteries and supercapacitors under all-weather environment conditions [165]. 3.5 COF membranes for other electrochemical applications In addition to being applied to various components of the above-mentioned SRBs, the construction of COFs with catalytic, selective adsorption, high electronic-conductivity, and supramolecular adhesive properties has also shown great potential in the field of other chemical powers. Zhang et al. [118] reported fluorinated-COF membranes with a high permselectivity and increased battery lifespan, which indicate the functionalized COF nanochannels can provide selective permeability for secondary energy storage applications. Guo et al. [143] proposed a COF-based adhesive additive, which effectively improves the dynamic performance and cycling stability of the battery, contributing to the clear structure, abundant adsorption/catalytic sites, and multi-level pores that accelerate the infiltration of electrolytes. In addition, COF-based membranes can be applied in proton exchange membranes for high-performance fuel cells, attributing to extreme thermal/chemical stability. Therefore, COFs with functional diversity and COF membranes obtained through simple additive design have great potential for application in the field of secondary energy storage batteries. 4 Insights into ion transport in COF membranes The combination of a versatile and highly tunable ion transport mechanism makes COF membranes ideal for a wide range of applications in energy conversion/storage. COFs can achieve high ion conductivity, selectivity, and stability by leveraging ordered pore structures, surface functionalities, and confinement effects [5,95,166–168]. The uniform pore sizes of COFs enable size-exclusion effects, where ions are selectively transported based on their size and charge [166,169] (Fig. 11 a). Liu et al. [85] proposed COF electrolytes designed with pore sizes that allowed fast transport of Li+ ions to pass through while blocking larger ions or molecules. This sieving effect is particularly useful for enhancing the selectivity and efficiency of ion transport in electrochemical devices. Additionally, the characteristics of COF pores can be functionalized with ion-conducting groups (sulfonate, carboxylate, amine groups, or polyethylene oxide unit), which facilitate ion transport through hopping mechanisms [47,94,134,170] (Fig. 11b). In this process, ions hop from one functional group to another along the pore walls, bypassing the demand for liquid electrolytes. Lan et al. [171] designed a series of anhydride-based COFs with specifically zigzag hopping sites and zincophilic anhydride groups that can serve as ideal platforms to achieve enhanced electrochemical stability. This mechanism is especially advantageous in solid-state batteries, where COF membranes act as both separators and ion conductors. Meanwhile, the charged functional groups (sulfonate, ammonium) within COFs can electrostatically adsorb or repel charged ions, thus enhancing ion transport (Fig. 11c). These interactions not only improve ion conductivity but also contribute to the selectivity of COF membranes. Then, the nanoscale confinement of ions within COF pores can alter their transport behavior (Fig. 11d). In confined environments, ions may exhibit faster diffusion behavior due to reduced solvation shells or restricted movement in specific directions. This effect is particularly pronounced in COFs with hierarchical pore structures, where ions can move rapidly through larger channels while being selectively filtered through smaller pores. In addition to the mechanism discussion mentioned above, ion transport can occur via the Grotthuss mechanism [172], where protons or other ions [173] move through a cross-linked network of hydrogen bonds or coordinated sites in some COFs (Fig. 11e). This mechanism is highly efficient and does not require the physical movement of ions over long distances. COFs with functional groups capable of forming hydrogen bonds or coordination complexes are particularly well-suited for this type of ion transport. Additionally, the interfacial effects in COF-matrix composite membranes and redox-active sites in frameworks also influence ion transport. Despite the current discussion on ion transport based on COF structure, the crystallinity, morphology, size, and crystallographic orientation of COFs also significantly impact ion transport behavior [94,151,174,175]. Although there is currently limited research on the regulation of COFs crystal state to achieve satisfactory ion conductivity, the crystallinity of COFs remains a very important factor affecting ion conduction. However, the crystallinity regulation for COFs is more difficult than MOFs, attributed to the strong covalent bond between the building blocks and low reversibility of the bond formation. According to current research on the crystallinity of MOFs, a decrease in crystallinity will be beneficial for ion conductivity. However, due to the low reversibility of COF building blocks and covalent bonds, modulating the crystallinity of COFs is a very complex issue. A more systematic study on crystallinity still needs to comprehensively explore its impact in secondary batteries based on different COFs types and application directions. The study on the morphology and size of COFs is detailed in Section 2.2.3, where specific morphology and size can affect ion transport behavior and kinetic characteristics. It is worth discussing that the orientation regulation of COFs is another current research focus, especially in the fields of selective ion transport and secondary batteries. Through theoretical verification, it has been found that ions along the vertical direction of 1D channels have lower ion diffusion energy barriers, which is beneficial for achieving rapid ion conduction. Additionally, the orientation control of COF can be achieved through pressure-assisted mechanical assembly, making ion conduction more optimal in the direction with shorter ion transport paths, significantly improving ion conductivity. The above relatively macroscopic discussion has great industrial guidance value for the preparation and regulation of functional COF membranes and provides a profound understanding of realizing alkali metal batteries with optimized functional COF-based components. 5 Conclusions and perspectives As a type of emerging crystalline porous material, COFs exhibit infinite possibilities in energy storage/conversion owing to the tunable porosity, high thermal/chemical stability, and functionality for tailored ion transport. In terms of the current difficult processing limitation of COFs, some feasible strategies have been devised to fabricate COF membranes with exceptional thermal/electrochemical stability. These properties endow COF membranes to be ideal candidates as crucial components of SRBs such as separators, electrode/electrolyte interfaces, and solid-state electrolytes, further promoting fast ion conduction and mitigating side reactions from a microscopic perspective. Moreover, functional COF membranes can be employed as proton exchange membranes for high-performance fuel cells. In conclusion, processable COF membranes can provide a feasible method for fabricating high-energy density, high-safety, environmental-friendly, and wide-temperature energy-storage devices. Despite significant advances, there are still a series of unresolved issues, including functionalized COF hybrids, Zwitterion pore design, ion conductivity that can be designed for various components of secondary rechargeable batteries, in-situ EEI engineering, and scalability of COF membranes, which are still a series of topics that need to be further explored. The design of COFs building block, modification of COF pores (size, surface characteristics, and host-guest interaction), COFs particle morphology/size, and preparation of COF hybrids (MOF-COFs, COF-MOFs, and POM-COFs, etc.) have great guiding value for the development of rechargeable alkali metal batteries. The functional design of COFs can be used to construct components with high ion conductivity, electronic conductivity, specific pore size, and host guest response, which can be applied to guide the manufacturing of specific functional components in secondary batteries, achieving optimized and enhanced electrochemical performance of secondary batteries [48,176–180]. Significantly, conventional powder morphology and imperfect processes for preparing membranes pose significant barriers to the application in commercial processes for next-generation rechargeable batteries. The scalability of COF membranes synthesis and its mechanical robustness under extreme conditions or long-term cycling remain significant challenges in terms of membrane stability and compatibility with battery components. The complex framework structure of COFs leads to high costs. Thus, further exploration of cost-effective preparation methods is imperative to reduce costs and achieve a trade-off between stability and crystallinity for COF membranes. For battery applications, the complex interface formation process and ion transfer behavior between electrodes and electrolytes still require in-depth investigation. Moreover, it is crucial to elucidate the nonnegligible impacts from in-situ interface generation on electrodes accompanied by the side reactions from reacting solvents. Through rigorous insights into these mechanism properties, theoretical guidance can be provided for designing functional COF membranes to enhance their electrochemical performance in secondary batteries. Overall, COF membranes have been successfully applied in various rechargeable secondary batteries by leveraging the intrinsic advantages of COFs and the current progress in membrane formation methods. Emerging applications, beyond alkali metal batteries, should be investigated to broaden the application scene of COF membranes in other energy storage systems (e.g., supercapacitors, and fuel cells). Exploration of machine learning and computational modeling for COFs design and scalable manufacturing techniques for commercial applications are also top priorities for future development. Research interests include solid-state lithium metal batteries, NASICON-type electrolytes and covalent organic frameworks. Gen Zhang, Young-thousand-talent Professor at the School of Chemistry and Chemistry at Nanjing University of Science and Technology. Gen received his PhD in chemistry from Lanzhou University in 2013. coredata.dc:description: Noteworthy challenges such as severe side reactions, interfacial instability, and dendrite growth have plagued rechargeable alkali metal batteries for a long time. Alleviating the plight necessitates innovative membranes capable of modulating ion transport and establishing stable interfaces. The exploration of implemented membranes with thermal/mechanical and electrochemical stability is crucial for achieving high-performance and safe alkali metal batteries. Crystalline covalent organic framework (COF) membranes have emerged as promising materials for next-generation energy storage systems due to their tunable porosity and exceptional physicochemical properties. This review specifically examines the critical role of COF membranes in enabling sustainable alkali metal (Li/Na/K) batteries, with a particular focus on design principles, performance advantages, and key challenges of COF membranes. The discussion emphasizes structure-property relationships specifically relevant to rechargeable battery applications, supported by recent decades of research. Impressively, this mini review further identifies three critical research frontiers: reticular chemistry-guided materials design, multifunctional composite architectures, and in-situ characterization techniques. This targeted analysis provides actionable insights for developing COF membranes that address the fundamental limitations of current alkali metal battery technologies.
